Curriculum 3.17.14.pdf                                              Academics                   Home > Academics > Undergraduate > BS > Overview                                                                       BS                Overview   Eligibility   Curriculum   Apply   FAQ   Traditional Four-Year Bachelor of Science (BS)   NYU College of Nursing offers a Bachelor of Science (BS) that prepares students to take the National Council Licensure Examination (NCLEX) for registered nurses to obtain licensure. High school graduates enter the four-year Bachelor of Science program as freshmen in the fall semester.   NYU College of Nursing’s goal is to prepare students to practice in a range of clinical settings in today’s challenging health care system. Students are challenged to examine the social, emotional, cultural, and environmental context in which wellness and illness occur. Students gain a scientific basis for and holistic perspective on the nurse’s role in promoting the health potential of individuals, families, and communities. Nursing courses offer increasing levels of knowledge and skills for addressing health needs throughout the lifespan.   The BS program combines a strong core of arts and science courses with a progression of nursing courses that provide increasing levels of knowledge and skills for addressing health needs throughout the lifespan.   The 128-credit curriculum for freshmen incorporates 44 credits of liberal arts courses, 20 credits of science and prerequisite courses, and 64 credits of nursing core and clinical courses. In addition to courses in the NYU College of Nursing, students take courses in NYU’s College of Arts and Sciences and Steinhardt School of Culture, Education, and Human Development. Since nursing courses begin in the junior year, BS students are able to take advantage of the university’s international study programs during their sophomore year. NYU College of Nursing encourages students to continue their studies with programs that allow for a seamless transition from undergraduate to graduate placement.   NYU College of Nursing graduates are in demand at major health care facilities throughout the country. Recent graduates are now working at premier institutions in New York City, e.g., NYU Langone Medical Center, Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, Mt. Sinai Hospital, Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, Bellevue Hospital, New York-Presbyterian, and major academic health care centers across the country, as well as positions in home health care agencies. Curriculum.pdf            Spring Start Fifteen-Month B.S. Curriculum.pdf                                              Academics                   Home > Academics > Undergraduate > Accelerated BS > Overview                                                                       Accelerated BS                Overview   Eligibility   Curriculum   Apply   FAQ   15-Month Accelerated Bachelor of Science Program   Prospective students with a baccalaureate degree in another field can apply to NYU College of Nursing’s Bachelor of Science (BS) in Nursing program’s accelerated track provided they have successfully completed the following nursing prerequisite courses prior to starting the program: nutrition, chemistry (with lab), statistics, anatomy and physiology (I and II), microbiology, and developmental psychology. The 15-month program is completed in four consecutive semesters (fall, spring, summer, fall or spring, summer, fall, spring) of full time study.   The 15-month accelerated BS program prepares students to take the National Council Licensure Examination for Registered Nurses (NCLEX) to obtain licensure. Accelerated students may enter the program in the fall (September) or spring (January) semester.   NYU College of Nursing’s goal is to prepare students to practice in a range of clinical settings in today’s challenging health care system. Students are challenged to examine the social, emotional, cultural, and environmental context in which wellness and illness occur. Students gain a scientific basis for and holistic perspective on the nurse’s role in promoting the health potential of individuals, families, and communities. Nursing courses offer increasing levels of knowledge and skills for addressing health needs throughout the lifespan.   Accelerated BS students are admitted to the College as undergraduates with 44 advanced standing credits in the liberal arts and 20 advanced credits in the sciences (based on credits earned while obtaining a bachelor’s degree plus additional prerequisite requirements completed prior to matriculation to the college). NYU College of Nursing encourages students to continue their studies with programs that allow for a seamless transition from undergraduate to graduate placement.   NYU College of Nursing graduates are in demand at major health care facilities throughout the country. Recent baccalaureate graduates are now working at premier institutions in New York City, e.g., NYU Langone Medical Center, Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, Mt. Sinai Hospital, Bellevue Hopital, and New York-Presbyterian, and major academic health care centers across the country, as well as positions in home health care agencies. Mental Health Nursing                                                                                     < Back Advanced Certificate Program in Advanced Practice Nursing: Mental Health Nursing Program Highlights     Innovative academic and clinical preparation in advanced practice adult psychiatric-mental health nursing across the lifespan   Opportunity to develop subspecialty expertise in substance related disorders   Direct collaboration with nationally and internationally renowned faculty in the field of psychiatric-mental health nursing and substance related disorders   Participate in spearheading innovative social change   Graduates of this program are eligible for the ANCC Family and Mental Health Nurse Practitioner Certification Examination       Program Requirements: 12-36 credits, 750 clinical hours   Courses                Advanced Practice Core (15 credits)                                                                                     NURSE-GN 2020       Spring                      NURSE-GN 2012               Advanced Physical Assessment Across the Lifespan              (3)             Fall, Spring                      NURSE-GN 2021               Clinical Pharmacotherapeutics Across the Lifespan              (3)             Fall, Spring                      NURSE-GN 2013               Contemporary Clinical Practice: Advanced Practice Roles              (3)             Spring, Summer                  Population Component - Psychiatric-Mental Health (21 credits)                                                                                     NURSE-GN 2136               Mental Health I: Individual Psychotherapy Across the Lifespan              (3)             Fall                      NURSE-GN 2137               Mental Health II: Foundation of Psychiatric Advanced Practice Nursing Across the Lifespan              (3)             Spring                      NURSE-GN 2138               Mental Health III: Group, Couple, and Family Psychotherapy Across the Lifespan              (3)             Summer                      NURSE-GN 2139               Mental Health IV: Adult and Geriatric Psychiatric Advanced Practice
